1hMw2GmW1mAxg9-xH4K41Q.text: I was drawn by the long queue every time I pass by the row of shophouses near Bugis Village and finally got to join the queue one day. They have a robust system with the assigning of tables. They will ask each person in the queue how many people they are expecting and they will only ask each group to go in when everyone in the group reaches. Usually the first seats that become available are at the counter but if you prefer to wait for a table, that's fine. Waiting outside the restaurant can be hot and it's annoying if people sit and smoke but the restaurant is considerate in offering free flow of ice tea for people in the queue. Trivial point but I was surprised that the restaurant played the same Japanese song throughout the night. I thought it's because of the speaker outside the restaurant but when I went in, the same song still played. Service was great and the waitress had a sense of humour when we came up with weird names for the order sheets. Food was good with every item meeting expectations. My friend could not finish her portion but it might just be because she's a small eater. Seating space can be a bit cramped and stuffy but we still sat for 1 hour plus. If you are here for the food, perhaps wait until off-peak hours like after 8:30am to skip the queue!

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Ramen special

MRZb_Aop8qY9IGqUR-EChg.text: Very disappointed. == Food ==They have an ordering sheet where you have some level of customisation on your ramen. Whether you want to add seaweed, eggs, noodles texture, soup taste, etc. We ordered a Summer (Spicy Pork) and an Autumn ramen. They were super speedy. We probably received our noodles in like less than 2mins. Drinks came in probably less than 30secs.The noodles were a major disappointment. The soup was very salty, the pork was a mega piece that was hard to tear and did not taste fresh.They had complementary bean sprout and hard boiled egg for dine in customers. A little fancy small bowl with sesame seeds that you can pound on your own. We only made it slightly close to half of the bowl. Just felt it wasn't worth eating anymore. == Ambience & Service ==The external decoration was really nice and they had newspaper clippings of being featured. In addition, I came across quite a number of their restaurant before so I figured it was fine giving it a shot.The staff were all dressed up well, and tries to be very prompt. Just a tad intrusive.The interior decor was really fancy too. I would say good attempt on the decor that create the Japanese environment/mood.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Ramen
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Ramen
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore

rEltSnfMJVO1lG7vDaacPA.text: The restaurant was colorful decorated, with bright colored paintings decorated the walls. It was interesting that there was tatami mats on the chairs surrounding the counter. One can customize the ramen here, similar to other outlets.  Remember to help yourself to the free flow hard boiled eggs, marinated bean sprouts. There's DIY to ground sesame seeds. There were various condiments also available. Ice water is served after placing order. Tonkotsu Ramen King ($13.90++)Instead of the usual char Siew, it was served with stir-fried pork with ginger on top. Barely tasted the ginger, but the pork was tender and flavourful with lots of caramelised onions.Tonkotsu Ramen Autumn ($12.90++)The pork soup base ramen dish was topped with minced meat and finely chopped mushrooms. It added an earthy taste to the creamy and rich soup. If you happen to visit the restaurant during your birthday, you will get a freebies too.The ramen was not bad. The staff were friendly and chatty too.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Tonkotsu Ramen Autumn
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore

i9-oa0NsnWEL1KyZ-tQcHQ.text: When I first walked in, the staff and many customers turned around to stare at me. Customers continued, literally turning in their seats to keep staring as I walked to my seat. That was awkward. I guess people in Singapore keep their looks pretty bland, but I am getting tired of all the gawking. I got the summer ramen. The broth was pretty spicy and creamy and overall it was aight. The spiciness covered most other flavors that might've been there rather than enhancing. On the order sheet I marked no black fungus, but got it anyway. The waiters are brusque and loud. I couldn't understand most of what they were yelling at me. I did appreciate the quick service. You pay up front with the order sheet they hand to you. This place was ok, but with just ramen on the menu and an unimpressive first visit, it's unlikely that I'll be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Summer ramen.

9XVfkROFogzdPDpuysh_Cw.text: This is nice like ippudo. Difference is the free boiled egg and bean sprouts. Oh and the business model. Your basically paying 10 bucks and optioning out your extras. So it can be a good deal or average deal depending on how you choose. I doubt you can have this business model in other countries where people would stuff their pockets with boiled eggs. Actually you can order a flavored egg for extra or take the free one? I think normally other places just put it in for free with a higher base price. Ok I'm bored talking about it. You know the green tea cola doesn't taste like green tea. Actually I tasted something like this before but I can't remember where. It's nice but not green tea flavored like I expected. There is "green tea" in the ingredients though.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Pain in ass. Don't care if it's free!
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore

Uc40hqQwc3xBzlzE74LtOw.text: On a hot steamy day you get the idea that you want a hot steamy soup.  It gets fixed in your head and desperately look for a ramen shop near Bugis. Quickly ushered to the bar, sesame seeds on the left, bean sprouts on the right, a stack of boiled eggs in front - you order a ramen.  I kept it simple but you can go to town in any of the 4 varieties of ramen. Don't worry, the shop remains fairly traditional with the ramen types.  I had to order a beer, but you can just get water or tea.  broth is thick (as it should), meat is sweeter and a bit tougher.than norm, noodles well cooked. flavors are ok. It is just...  far from a divine experience, there is no wow factor. Broth is missing its soul.   Memorable? No. Will come again? Only if I'm desperate.

ePQdpEnz0Ch_chLBwhSRCQ.text: I am pretty fussy when it comes to ramen just because it's one of my fave Japanese food and I don't mind eating it everyday! So far I think this Tonkotsu King chain shop is the best compare to other branches.I just love everything about this ramen shop, here's why:Free flow eggs! I always eat at least 5 eggs there...The rich broth!The fact that everything is optional, you get to choose what you want or don't want to be in your ramen, hence making it possible to pay a cheaper price and I like my ramen to be basic anyway.I always go for Winter Ramen which is the simplest yet most satisfying for me. It's so authentic and delicious. It kinda reminds me a little bit of Ichiran Ramen in Japan. The meat is the perfect cut for ramen, it is so tender, thick and juicy too. Such an impressive combo and hopefully they'll keep up their standard for the crowds. Oh, don't forget to order some rice dishes if you're still hungry after that bowl of ramen because they taste great as well! Or if you're feeling thrifty just order white rice and throw it in the broth, plain tasty!

2NbsaM-NmLdi_HMjHTxfWA.text: So I've been here like 5 times collecting PERX points which is an app on your phone that collects stamps. For every bowl of ramen you buy, you get a stamp and if you get 8 stamps you get one free $12.90 ramen bowl. So anyways I was here on Thursday night and again on Saturday afternoon and I am very certain that the chef put a ton more MSG into the soup broth today. I was dying of thirst the second I walked out. I gulped down my cup of ice water and after I paid, the cooler of barley tea meant to entertain the guests queuing up was very tempting to me! :( so yeah... I dunno about coming back here now...

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Autumn ramen with egg! :D yummy!!~
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Munch on sauteed bean sprouts or hard boiled eggs while waiting for your ramen :)
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. The queue on a Friday night at 6:45pm

UhDrNu767eNMb-kz0_UH9w.text: Delicious ramen from the Keisuke chain. The summer ramen is a little spicy and quite shiok and the autumn ramen is porky and satisfying. The broth is rich with collagen - very decadent mouthfeel.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Autumn ramen
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Summer ramen.

NZCaBUChDbwi1Xb_BJRmZA.text: Delicious broth. Quite authentic very rich broth. Free flow of eggs and green bean sprout.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Nice decoration.

NbV9o5kzjSn1RwFQpeTpXA.text: I've always thought with so many styles of ramen and soup bases, the 'very good' and 'excellent' are hard to distinguish, that, or I haven't quite refined my palette yet. I just seem to like soupy noodles. And on that note, here we go.Free bean sprouts. Free boiled egg. That's a pretty good start in my books! Very modest menu with 4 versions of ramen served, 'Spring' is with basil and cheese, 'Summer' is spicy pork minced, 'autumn' is pork minced with bonito flavour & fried mixed mushrooms, and 'winter' is the humble pork broth ramen. I went with humble. Lovely soup base. But Im not hard to please. I did find the portion of ramen noodles quite small. They have the option, if you're still hungry afterwards, to order 'kaedama' which is the ordering of extra noodles for $2. But the very cynical side of me says the original portion is smaller, so that you end up ordering kaedama. Or that's the conspiracist in me thinking out loud. Other than that small blemish, the experience is a delight. Ramen noodles is a pretty quick affair. You slurp, and then move on. This establishment doesn't complicate things with unnecessary menu items. So if you just want your noodles, give this a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Kaedama available here!
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. Winter. Pork broth ramen
Photo of Tonkotsu King Four Seasons - Singapore, Singapore. As much bean sprouts as you can handle

sWOMnbG5XszvFp4PoLdTWA.text: After hearing rave reviews from my friends regarding a ramen place around the Bugis area, I brought my friend to this ramen shop, opened by the Ramen Keisuke chain, which is headed by the ramen king of the Ramen Champion series back in Tokyo, Chef Keisuke Takeda. This is also their 4th outlet here.There's free boiled eggs and beansprouts. The marinated beansprouts tasted awesome and refreshing!I had a Tonkotsu Ramen Winter with All Toppings. This was basically the normal tonkotsu ramen, one should have in the winter season. The all toppings added jew's ear, seaweed, soft-boiled egg and stir-fried pork into the ramen. The broth was thick and not at all salty, the ramen tasted chewy. The seaweed came in a big piece, something which I didn't really expect. The soft-boiled egg was cooked perfectly, silky and full of flavour. The stir-fried pork was excellent too, chewy and flavourful.My friend had a Tonkotsu Ramen Autumn with All Toppings. Autumn is minced pork with bonitos flavour with fried mixed mushroom. The minced pork tasted great alongside with the mixed mushroom. Otherwise, the same taste for Winter applies here.A definitely must come to place for a ramen lover. It is no wonder that this place is in the tops for best ramen in Singapore, though in comparisons to other ramens I have eaten this place will definitely be in the lead, making the 40 minutes that I have waited in the queue just to get seated worthwhile. Do get the Green Tea Cola while you are here!

0o9tzAPPWO-PK7wgprqzPQ.text: Now if you've seen the other two Keisuke Tonkotsu King branches, you'll know I'm a big fan.But I honestly feel I can't give this branch any more than 4 stars because of the service.I had the autumn flavour, which had minced mushroom and pork (I think). It was a nice change from the usual straight Tonkotsu King options, but still back up by their super rich broth. Let's be honest here.ANYTHING with that broth will be good. It's so rich that it should be TAXABLE. It's that good!And basically, put any (reasonable) combination of flavour enhancers like pork, mushroom, spicy miso, bonito, ANYTHING with noodles and douse it in that soup base? It'll be good.Why is the service worth docking a star for though?DECEIT. I was quite happy to notice that this branch accepts credit cards. They have stickers and signs, and in particular, my primary daily use card is an AMEX card. There's a BIG sticker saying Amex accepted here. The pen next to the cashier is an Amex pen. WELL GUESS WHAT. They don't accept Amex. W. T. F. Then take down that sticker and throw away that pen because I accept that not every stall accepts Amex, but don't mislead me into not going to the ATM before I dine at your restaurant just because you want to PRETEND that you accept Amex.So. The ramen? Still awesome. Still worth the visit.But man, this whole credit card thing just left such a bad taste in my mouth.

QkzslYCm81-WdSoiSqwCsA.text: Uh oh - one of the best ramen places is now only a short walk away from my humble abode. This could be addictive!Everyone seems to have their unique preference for noodles. Tonkotsu suits my preference in the heavy rich soup they serve as its akin to Jangara ramen in Tokyo which still stands as my number one choice in Japan. Its quite creamy and not everyone's taste, but each season on the menu has a different broth to cater for differing palates. I can't comment on the other choices for now, but it suffices to say that the Tonkotsu King special is excellent. The menu option also allows one to adjust the broth's taste and the noodle hardness. If you want it like the Japanese then I recommend the hard noodles.Kaidama is the genius option of having another serving of noodles 'as is' which you can put straight into the soup you had served first. The noodle servings are rather miserly so this is a good option for the hungry at little extra cost.Pickled bean sprouts and boiled eggs are complimentary. The prices are somewhat higher than they would be in Japan but I am still a wiling buyer.

brpcvp5pmeJEqTLRQWQ5Cg.text: Pretty small walkway outside to have a long line - good thing I came when the line wasn't that crazy; however, it provided tea in case you got thirsty while waiting. Although it had menu with pictures to make ordering easier, you also need to fill in an order form that you submit to the waiter to help the ordering part faster and done correctly to your need since you can pick different kind of noodles, soup saltiness, toppings, drinks, etc. They have 4 different soup base to match each season in a year - I chose the cheese and basil tonkotsu ramen. While waiting for the food, you can fill yourself with the free boiled egg that can be eaten with mayonaise. The entree itself is good and very reasonably priced for the portion.
